It turns out there is a skip plugin for nose, which allows you to explicitly skip test cases. It might be better to use that so they know the tests have been explicitly skipped whereas other issues might cause 0 tests to be run (e.g. some code might cause an early return). It also allows us to give a reason for skipping a test.

I can reproduce this issue after 100 trials auto tvm tunning on ARM CPU, but can not reproduce without auto tvm tunning.

```python
input_sym = nnvm.sym.Variable('data')
alpha = nnvm.sym.Variable('alpha')
net = nnvm.sym.conv2d(input_sym, channels=3, kernel_size=(1,1), padding=(0,0), strides=(1, 1), use_bias=False)
net = nnvm.sym.prelu(data=net, alpha=alpha, axis=1)
params = {'alpha': tvm.nd.array(np.ones((3,), dtype=dtype))}
```

The issue is that when we apply schedule of conv2d combined prelu we emit wrong LLVM IR. For example, we would emit this kind of LLVM IR:

```LLVM
%72 = fcmp ogt <16 x float> %68, zeroinitializer
br <16 x i1> %72, label %if_end, label %if_else
```

However, `br` instruction can not accept `<N x i1>` type, which only accept `i1` type. Please see this link: https://llvm.org/docs/LangRef.html#br-instruction

So, we can add condition type check of `UnsafeSelectRewriter` to avoid this issue. i.e. to make sure condition type is just `i1`, not other things else.

I can help make a PR to resolve this issue soon.
@FrozenGene, thanks for the answer, good to know you've resolved the issue.

```
This will create lib/libtvm_web_runtime.bc and lib/libtvm_web_runtime.js
```

So the following step "Use TVM to Generate Javascript Library" does not work

Following the code I saw that the object can be specified with the runtime so lets harcode it:
```python
import os
import tvm
from tvm.contrib import emscripten

def prepare_test_libs(base_path):
    target = "llvm -target=asmjs-unknown-emscripten -system-lib"
    if not tvm.module.enabled(target):
        raise RuntimeError("Target %s is not enbaled" % target)
        
    n           = tvm.var("n")
    A           = tvm.placeholder((n,), name='A')
    B           = tvm.compute(A.shape, lambda *i: A(*i) + 1.0, name='B')
    s           = tvm.create_schedule(B.op)
    fadd1       = tvm.build(s, [A, B], target, name="add_one")
    obj_path    = os.path.join(base_path, "test_add_one.bc")
    fadd1.save(obj_path)

    harcoded_runtime = "/root/tvm/lib/libtvm_web_runtime.bc"
    emscripten.create_js( os.path.join(base_path, "test_module.js"), harcoded_runtime)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    curr_path = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(os.path.expanduser(__file__)))
    prepare_test_libs(os.path.join(curr_path, "../../lib"))
```

Since this PR fixes some bugs that other PRs are pending on. I am going to merge this in. 

The proposed change of ```weight_layout->kernel_layout``` needs some further discussion(in particular, the meaning of the "kernel", does it refer to the weight, or only spatial part of the weight), but because relay has not been released as a stable branch and ```kernel_layout``` was closer to NNVMv1, I won't view this as a regression for now.
Thanks to @merrymercy @jroesch @vinx13 @srkreddy1238 @zhiics @yzhliu
This is a bit strange, shall we make sure the condition of prelu is bool instead?

@tmoreau89 It shouldn't be hard if you only want to offload most of ops to VTA and only keep a few to CPU. Otherwise, I think it might be a little tedious to traverse the program and add `on_device` ops. Another way might make annotation easier is probably to allow users to just provide relay op names instead of adding `on_device` primitives directly, and we can add these primitives in the backend. How do you think?
@zhiics Could you use git rebase so that it will include your commits?
oops. Sorry. I will rebase now.
Thanks to @joshpoll @wweic , this is now merged
dropout is simplified away in simplify inference, so we it is not necessary to add its type for now
Prelu is implemented in select statement, prelu helps us expose this issue. In theory, we can constrtuct other cases using select (condition type is N x i1) to expose this issue.
@yzhliu Yes, we need to use `relay.on_device` to do annotation. I think we can also allow users to provide the op names for annotation as well, but that probably is worthy a separate PR.
@tqchen Thanks.

Supplement of previous comment. LLVM select instruction can accept i1 or vector of i1 (N xi1) type, see: https://llvm.org/docs/LangRef.html#select-instruction But br can only accept i1 type, so this is why I say we can construct using select (N x i1) to expose this issue.
FoldScaleAxis need this pass to check the constantness and positiveness of scale.

@nhynes I'm working on the common crate and it's completely non-obvious how to make it. I'm making minimum assumptions like even removing the debugging for `TVMValue` and including it raw same as in Rust runtime. The only idea that might lead to a solution is to include the entire `c_runtime_api.rs` in common and get rid of my `tvm-sys` which I don't like and it would impose very uncommon layout for a Rust binding. If I include some partial C runtime api such as `TVMValue` and `TVMTypeCode`, then Rust's orphan rule prevents me from conversion from `common::TVMValue` to `tvm_sys::TVMValue` and need to change all occurences of `tvm_sys::TVMValue` in the raw api to `common::TVMValue` which is not possible!

I'm now thinking maybe common crate is not a good idea here and we can have exactly the same functionalities with two different implementations because runtime and frontend needs are different when we include debugging for example. Note that this includes very basic value conversions API only and it's not significant.

Overall, I'll work on making a common crate this week and next maybe and if I wouldn't have found a solution by then, I'd just change the frontend `TVMRetValue` to exactly match the runtime and impl the same conversions and send the PR. 

Any comment?
Thanks to @liwchang this is now merged.
Thanks, @liwchang , this is  now merged
We do need this folder due to the fact that FoldScaleAxis need to check the constantness and positiveness, please add a comment on that block for now.

Thanks, @FrozenGene for the explaination. I have a follow-up PR that is related https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2389 The root cause of this error is when if_then_else get vectorized which causes incorrect semantics.
Thanks, @yangchen-MS, @zhiics  ! this is now merged
So far there is not too many flaky cases, if there are, we should fix the test-case to relax the bound, and nail down the flay testcases

Thanks.

I encountered one in logSoftMax today.

Let's keep this thread for a few while. 
I think others might wanna report it.

As per current guideline, https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md we try to close issues aggressively and make that sure each issue is actionable.  This approach avoids a huge pile of issues that nobody gets attend to. So I would recommend close this one, open a thread in https://discuss.tvm.ai/  and open separate actionable items as issues, for example:

- https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/2109
- https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/1784

Sure.
At the host, do you mind creating a thread, so everyone can report to the same one?  :)

For an actionable item, I still suggest avoiding using pure random numbers, at least we should fix seeds.
Thanks, @zhiics , @tqchen !

The random number is useful for test-cases and I believe in most cases, as long as we make sure the ranges are right(correct interval of the distribution for certain functions) or have the right tol value, most cases are not flaky.  Using random number can sometimes help us find problems.
centralized thread created per your suggestion https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/flaky-test-cases-thread/1437

I believe this is a bug, the way to reproduce this is to run the notebook in ipython command line and everything works as expected, but when running from the python notebook I get the failure described in the first comment.
This is probably some interaction between the network connection of the notebook and the network connection to the slaves running tasks?
Thanks @denis0x0D @grwlf @yzhliu !This is now merged !

@liwchang This patch is only correct for specific processors and compilers, for example, MSVC provides release semantics for writing, and acquire semantics for reading volatile objects. In principle, volatility ensures neither atomicity nor memory consistency. I suggest you consider std::atomic instead.

CC: @tqchen

@junrushao1994 For the correctness, it should be correct, due to that **lock**.
Of course you can use few atomics to replace the lock.
I did think about using atomics, but I chose minimal change.
Feel free to change it.
-L

@liwchang Thank you for the explanation!

So we know that .lock() and.unlock() has provided sequential consistency, which is cool. Also, before writing to the flag, the cache lines on other processors are typically invalidated. So why this issue exists? Or you mean the compiler did a common subexpression elimination over the flag which leads to the bug?

an interesting point. what happens if the `common` crate has the headers behind one of two mutually exclusive feature flags: `runtime` and `frontend`? The former would pull in the definitions from `c_runtime_api.rs` and the latter would expose `tvm-sys`.

> removing the debugging 

I'm not sure I follow. Is it not as easy as `#[derive(Debug)]` or even `impl Debug for Struct`

Like even if we have to do out-of-band codegen, I think that it's worth having one API. If we don't, SWIM will surely come by in a few months, read the codebase, and think "wtf. why are there two different implementations of the same thing?!?!" much as I do when reading topi code :P 

I'd prefer for you to not struggle with this, so if it really becomes too onerous, just give me your acceptance criteria for the frontend "working" and I'll do my best to merge them.

Simply the flag is set too early before initialization really happening.

Again, you can introduce atomic or release/acquire.
I just chose minimal working change.
Feel free to change it.

@tqchen I think normal (runtime) Rust doesn't need `unpack_lib` [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/Jenkinsfile#L146) whereas frontend Rust needs `unpack_lib('cpu', tvm_multilib)` (that's why the frontend PR build fails due to not finding `libtvm_runtime.so`). So if you want to make them all in the same test script, we can put runtime Rust where it has access to `tvm_multilib` and separate them when we have more resources later!

I should have been more careful when reporting the issue. The failure happened when running nnvm/tests/python/frontend/onnx for CPU target. My TVM built with LLVM 6.0.1. To reproduce the failure (hopefully you could reproduce it because it might be arch-related), you can replace:

    x = np.random.uniform(size=in_shape).astype(dtype)

with

        x = np.asarray([[[[ 0.94189703, 0.24268626, 0.25545985],
                      [ 0.95224684, 0.57228124, 0.63862652],
                      [ 0.93324018, 0.87410188, 0.62078589]],
                     [[ 0.21460213, 0.86773658, 0.62907255],
                      [ 0.18104482, 0.82294154, 0.26680526],
                      [ 0.411677,   0.03111285, 0.11248256]]]], dtype='float32')

in function test_single_ops in nnvm/tests/python/frontend/onnx/test_forward.py, and run a similar command like below:

    python -m nose -v ../nnvm/tests/python/frontend/onnx/test_forward.py

To reproduce the issue, you may try the following patch:

    diff --git a/nnvm/tests/python/frontend/onnx/test_forward.py b/nnvm/tests/python/frontend/onnx/test_forward.py
    index 82b5d319..d20b0521 100644
    --- a/nnvm/tests/python/frontend/onnx/test_forward.py
    +++ b/nnvm/tests/python/frontend/onnx/test_forward.py
    @@ -273,7 +273,7 @@ def test_slice():
         _test_slice_iteration(x, x[:, 0:-1], (0), (-1), (1))

     def _test_onnx_op_elementwise(inshape, outfunc, npargs, dtype, opname, kwargs):
    -    indata = np.random.uniform(-1, 1, size=inshape).astype(dtype)
    +    indata = np.asarray([[0.69074488, 0.29226714,-0.56205946, 0.01265035]], dtype='float32')
         outdata = outfunc(indata, **npargs)

         y = helper.make_node(opname, ['in'], ['out'], **kwargs)

And run a command similar to this one:

    python -m nose -v ../nnvm/tests/python/frontend/onnx/test_forward.py

Note that make sure to setup PYTHONPATH correctly before running the command.

I think we may want to adjust '```rtol``` for these failing tests. The reason is that different FP-related algorithms (e.g. vectorization algorithm used by LLVM, or CUDA library) could produce results with different accuracy. For example, we might want to check only 3 or 4 most significant digits after dot.

@yangchen-MS can you send in a PR to adjust the rtols and atol(of the recently reported flaky case). We can use tvm.testing.assert_allclose which sets the atol correctly. 

In some cases, we might need to fix the way random numbers are generated(e.g. Div, (x/y) we will need to make sure y is not too small)

OK, to think a bit more on this part. We may indeed need to set initialized_ to be atomic, mainly because if we observed the effect of initializing, the ordering need to guarantee that the previous actions are already released. 

This is particularly problematic when initalized_ is observed but the ordering is not guaranteed because the current thread never grabs the lock. 

A correct way to implement this would be make initialized_ atomic and use load acquire and store release in the final step.
